intro: Dodecatheon meadia var. macrocarpum, commonly known as the showy peony or large-fruited globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the central and eastern United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant produces distinctive, round, red or orange seed pods that split open to release seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands and prairies. Its botanical features make it a notable species for both ecological and ornamental purposes.
